awd_titl_txt: Crowdsourcing the Sky with the NOIRLab Source Catalog
awd_abstract_narration:
The all-sky NOIRLab Source Catalog (NSC) is a catalog of nearly all the data, taken by astronomers over many years that is resident in NOIRLab’s image archive.  This data includes information on three quarters of the sky and is available for exploration with innovative big data techniques that will also be useful for other large surveys such as that to be obtained with the Rubin Observatory. This project will use the database to address two important science questions regarding asteroids and pulsating stars. There are many asteroids in our solar system, some of which are nearby and could potentially impact the earth. Astronomers have been trying to catalog most of them over the last couple of decades. The NSC can help with this effort as it is able to detect fainter asteroids than most current searches and covers parts of the sky not previously explored. Large scale structures in our Milky Way galaxy can be mapped and explored by finding certain types of pulsating stars for which distances can be accurately determined from previous studies.  The project includes a plan to involve tens of thousands of citizen scientists to assist in various aspects of the project notably to find stars that have change position on the sky.

New techniques are needed to extract important scientific information and insights from both existing data sets and future large data such as the Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST) at the Rubin Observatory. The all-sky NOIRLab Source Catalog (NSC) is a catalog of nearly all public data in NOIRLab’s image archive. The NSC covers three quarters of the sky going substantially deeper than previous projects and includes data in areas never before cataloged. The project looks to explore the NSC to develop big data techniques focused on two science cases. The first of these is to search for high proper motion objects, especially Near-Earth Objects that could potentially impact the earth. Modern clustering algorithms such as Spectral Clustering and DBSCAN will be utilized to process the 68 billion measurements and provide a census of nearby objects. The second science investigation will be on searching for stellar variability. The time-series nature of the NSC will permit a search for objects that vary in brightness over time. This includes variable stars that are good tracers of the structure of the Milky Way. Non-parametric period estimation techniques and new variable star templates will be utilized to enable automatic and robust identification and classification of all variables in the NSC.  An extensive citizen scientist program is planned for assistance in the detection of proper motions of stars.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With the rise of the internet and cell phones equipped with digital cameras, crowdsourcing information has become an integral part of everyday life. The data is available — it's just a matter of sifting through it. This concept also extends to astronomy. Observing time on large telescopes is typically allocated to individual researchers usually in small increments of a few nights. The resulting images are used by researchers for their projects and eventually published in peer-reviewed journals. However, the data is rarely made available for broader use by other astronomers.

As a result, the global astronomy community has unknowingly collaborated on a vast, untapped survey of the sky, hidden within the archives of major observatories. This crowdsourced dataset forms the backbone of the NOIRLab Source Catalog (NSC), which utilizes the archive from NSF's National Optical-Infrared Astronomy Research Laboratory (NOIRLab). We have processed petabytes (thousands ofgigabytes) of data to uniformly detect and measure sources in the images and match-up the objects across different images to track their motion. The second data release features 68 billion measurements of 3.9 billion unique objects while the upcoming third data release will include 2-3 times as many measurements. The sheer scale and temporal richness of the NSC make it an invaluable resource for astronomical research.  In addition, the massive volume of this dataset necessitates the development of new techniques for analyzing it, a challenge we have also invested in.

Solar System Objects (SSOs), such as asteroids and comets, are ancient remnants from the formation of our solar system. Studying them can offer valuable insights into the origins of both our Solar System and Earth itself. However, SSOs also pose potential existential threats to life on Earth. The extinction of the dinosaurs was caused by a massive impact, and a similar event could occur again. To mitigate this risk, astronomers are actively cataloging asteroids to identify any that may pose a danger.


Detecting SSOs is a challenging task because they move quickly in the sky across our line of sight. To track them, astronomers must take multiple images of the same area of the sky in rapid succession — typically within an hour or two. This allows them to measure the object's angular speed and direction, known as a "tracklet." The tracklets are then linked together to calculate the full orbit of an SSO around the Sun. This process requires not only precise observations, but also specialized software and algorithms to analyze the data.  Fortunately, the NSC dataset is well-suited for detecting tracklets. Given the large volume of data from the NSC, automating this process is essential. We have developed software that automatically identifies SSOs and measures their angular speed and direction. We detected over 500,000 tracklets with many linked to determine the orbits of various SSOs. These detections have been submitted to the Minor Planet Center to assist in tracking potentially hazardous asteroids.


Pulsating stars are beacons scattered across the universe, offering valuable insights into the cosmos. They are sometimes referred to as the “cosmic heartbeat,” due to their rhythmic changes in brightness. One of the most remarkable features of pulsating stars is the relationship between their pulsation period and their intrinsic brightness or luminosity. In simple terms, the longer the pulsation period, the more luminous the star. Accurately determining distances to astronomical objects is generally quite challenging. Howver, knowing a pulsating star's luminosity allows us to accurately determine its distance. Because of this, pulsating stars are often referred to as "standard candles," providing a reliable method to measure distances across the universe.


Pulsating stars play a crucial role in the "cosmic distance scale," allowing us to gauge distances to stars and galaxies throughout the cosmos. Additionally, they are invaluable for exploring the structures within our own galaxy. Our work has led to the development of innovative techniques for detecting and classifying pulsating stars, even with noisier and less detailed data than was previously possible. Thanks to the extensive coverage of the NSC, we have cataloged pulsating stars that are farther away than those observed in other major astronomical surveys and open up new realms of discovery.


Finally, the NSC is an invaluable tool for detecting high proper motion (HPM) objects, which are typically located relatively close to our Sun. Since nearby objects appear to move faster across our line of sight compared to more distant ones, stars closer to us exhibit higher proper motions — greater angular speeds — across the sky. One effective method for identifying stars in our local cosmic neighborhood is by searching for these HPM objects and studying their motion. The temporal data provided by the NSC offers a unique opportunity to detect and track these stars. As a result, we have identified many new HPM objects, contributing to a more complete census of our local solar neighborhood.
